awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Collaborative Research: Do nearby surfaces limit the food uptake of microscopic sessile suspension feeders- 3D feeding flow measurements?
awd_abstract_narration:
Most of earth is covered by water, and it is essential to keep these ocean and freshwater ecosystems healthy. To do so, scientists must understand how they stay clean and in balance. A critical part of healthy bodies of water are microscopic organisms, which process waste and keep water clean by eating bacteria and debris. The feeding rate of these tiny organisms (how much water they clean per time) determines the impact they have on the health of their environments. Therefore, understanding this feeding rate is important both to predicting how bodies of water will react to change (e.g., pollution, sewage leaks, climate change) and determining how to promote the recovery of unhealthy bodies of water. One type of microscopic organism that is important for clean water and is ubiquitous in freshwater and marine environments is the surface-attached protist. These organisms live in dense aggregations attached to under-water surfaces, such as rocks, plants, and sinking debris and create feeding currents that draws their food to them. The investigators will use a novel holographic microscope to make the first three-dimensional measurements of feeding currents of these organisms in realistic conditions. The findings will be used to validate existing mathematical models of the feeding rates of these microscopic organisms and will inform the development of strategies to clean bodies of water and improve wastewater treatment plant performance. This project will also provide interdisciplinary opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM workforce.   


Microscopic sessile suspension feeders (MSSFs) are surface-attached protists that are a ubiquitous and critical component in aquatic ecosystems, performing the vital ecological function of removing bacteria and contaminants and serving as a key trophic intermediate between algae/bacteria and higher eukaryotic taxa. Previous studies of the feeding activity of these surface-attached protists have been limited to confined conditions that distort the flow and 2D measurements do not capture the non-axisymmetric nature of the current. Further, theory predicts that feeding is restricted by closed eddies in the flow caused by the surface of attachment, and that the impact of these eddies on feeding rate depends strongly on the angle of the MSSF with respect to the surface. The researchers will use Vorticella, a sessile ciliate, to determine whether food uptake of MSSFs is limited by the hydrodynamics of feeding attached to surfaces. Using a novel 3D holographic microscope, they will determine: (1) how the 3D feeding flow field of a single MSSF changes with body orientation of the organism relative to the surface, (2) how the dynamics of body orientation for Vorticella in culture compares to those in nature, (3) how feeding flows and body orientations affect food uptake, and (4) how the feeding flows are affected by ambient environmental flows. The measurements will be used to validate hydrodynamic models of MSSFs that can predict clearance rates. The resulting mechanistic understanding of microscopic interactions will ultimately build a foundation to scale up to community- and ecosystem-level processes to inform efforts to protect the health of aquatic ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An important part of healthy bodies of water are microscopic organisms that live attached to surfaces, like rocks, plants, and sinking particles. These single-celled organisms help keep water clean and in balance by eating bacteria and debris, and being eaten, in turn, by larger organisms. The feeding rate of these organisms determines the impact they have on the health of their environments. These feeding rates are also important to study because they affect the processes by which seawater contaminants such as oil and sewage pass though aquatic ecosystems, and these attached organisms can help clean up after human-caused contamination.  Previous measurements determined the feeding rate of these critical organisms, but only in still water and on flat surfaces, while they live in much more diverse conditions. This project focused on determining the interaction of the organisms’ own feeding current, which they generate to pull in food, with the flow of the water around them.

This project’s first major finding is that feeding rates of Vorticella convallaria, a representative species of attached microorganism, are very different in still versus moving water. Since most bodies of water have flow, our results can eventually help to more accurately predict how bodies of water will react to change (e.g., pollution, climate change) and determine how to promote the recovery of unhealthy bodies of water.

Our second significant finding was that, in ambient flow, the organisms’ natural condition, feeding rates are highly dependent on an individual organism’s orientation relative to the surface of attachment and the flow. We used 3D orientation measurements made with a custom microscope to show that V. convallaria orientation became progressively tilted downstream in faster flows, but that individuals were still able to actively reorient. This means that the feeding rate of these organisms may be reduced in environments with fast flow, and that understanding the ambient flow conditions where the organisms are attached is important to predicting their feeding rates and environmental impacts.

This project also studied how these attached microscopic organisms affect sinking aggregates. Sinking aggregates are a critical part of aquatic ecosystems. For instance, plentiful sinking aggregates, called marine snow, account for the majority of carbon sequestration in the ocean. These sinking aggregates are densely colonized by microscopic organisms, including many that generate feeding currents. We found that these feeding currents significantly change how water flows near the aggregates. We showed that these changes in flow are likely to affect aquatic system processes, such as aggregation rates, degradation rates, sinking speeds, and the composition of aggregates. Our results suggest a new paradigm for how aquatic sinking aggregates interact with their surroundings. In the past, they have been viewed as passive particles, subject to the flow around them, whereas our results show that the flows generated by attached organisms change both aggregate local flow and sinking dynamics. Our work on aggregates also provides a starting point for exploring the larger-scale implications of attached organisms on these system processes, which, in turn, are critical for understanding process such as carbon sequestration in the ocean or efficiency in waste-water treatment plants.

As well as the experimental results above, this project also confirmed that a simple calculational model for these attached organisms matches well the observed feeding currents that they generate. This will be helpful in predicting how changes in ambient flow or other environmental factors affect feeding rates. 

Overall, our project both discovered the important results above and is also a starting point for exploring the potentially important larger-scale implications of the attached organisms on system processes, whether it is productivity of seagrasses or the coagulation of particles in the ocean and in waste water treatment plants.

This work has also contributed to developing a more diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce, and improving STEM education. PI Pepper has introduced as successful Biophysics minor at the University of Puget Sound, trained 9 undergraduate students, 1 research technician, and one postdoctoral scholar in the research process. Many of these trainees are from groups underrepresented in science.

PI Pepper has also contributed to outreach for broad dissemination of this work and to increase interest in science among the general public. Pepper participated in the unique, “Science Stories’ project, which brings together artists and scientists to collaborate on artists books that “offer new ways to interpret science and to tell a story”.  The full project can be seen at https://blogs.pugetsound.edu/sciencestories/, and the work from this grant at https://blogs.pugetsound.edu/sciencestories/vorticella-convallaria-1676-2020/ . The project was exhibited in several venues, including at the University of Puget Sound. Pepper has also participated in the AAUW-WA Tech Trek Professional Women’s Night at Pacific Lutheran University. Tech Trek is a week-long STEM camp for middle school girls, and the goal of the Profession Women’s night is to expose girls to role models in STEM.
